awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Ultra-Efficient, Scalable, and Fault-Tolerant DC-DC Converters for Medium/High-Voltage Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
EAGER: Ultra-Efficient, Scalable, and Fault-Tolerant DC-DC Converters for Medium/High-Voltage Applications
   With the growing demand for exploiting distributed energy resources and the need for dynamic and reconfigurable power grids with ever    increasing power density, reliability, and efficiency requirements, the concept of direct current (dc) power systems is gaining traction. Lower losses and higher power densities enabled by dc power transmission and distribution has sparked further implementation of high-voltage and medium-voltage dc transmission and distribution systems. It is envisioned that the dc grids will improve functionality, stability, and reliability of the legacy power grid while simultaneously decreasing the conversion losses and investment cost.
   The envisioned dc grids are not necessarily at the same voltage level and their expansion towards the future grid calls for ultra- efficient, scalable, power-dense and fault-tolerant medium- and high-voltage dc-dc power converters, which will enable voltage matching when connecting two or more dc systems operating at different voltage levels. The objective of this research is to realize a new class of dc-dc converters, which pushes the boundaries of efficiency, scalability, power density and fault tolerance/reliability and expedites further expansion of  dc grids. To  this end, two  new promising converter topologies, one based on the voltage-sourced converter concept and the other one based on the current-sourced converter concept, are fully explored. The project will focus on modeling, analysis, control, short-circuit fault protection, and design optimization of these converter topologies, demonstrating the ability to achieve the objectives including compact, ultra-efficient, power dense, and embedded fault blocking capability. por.por_cntn:
With the growing demand for exploiting distributed energy resources and the need for dynamic and reconfigurable power grids with ever increasing power density and efficiency requirements, the concept of direct current (DC) power systems is gaining traction. Lower losses and higher power densities enabled by DC power transmission and distribution has sparked further implementation of high-voltage DC (HVDC) transmission systems, as well as medium-voltage DC (MVDC) distribution systems. It is envisioned that the MVDC and HVDC grids would improve functionality, stability, and reliability of the legacy power grid while simultaneously decreasing the conversion losses and investment cost. Today’s DC grids are predominantly HVDC transmission lines. In the very near future, however, the use of DC is expected to expand rapidly and to result in the implementation of full-blown DC grids, which will initially be built up gradually based on the interconnection of the existing DC lines. These DC grids are not necessarily at the same voltage level and their expansion towards the future grid calls for ultra-efficient, scalable and fault-tolerant MV and HV DC-DC converters, which will enable voltage matching when connecting two or more MVDC/HVDC systems operating at different voltage levels. In addition to enabling the interoperability of different MVDC/HVDC systems, such DC-DC converters will (i) permit the judicious segmentation of large DC grids into numerous protection zones composed of smaller DC networks, hence preventing system blackouts during severe contingencies; and (ii) enable the realization of an integrated DC collection and transmission system for grid integration and transmission of offshore wind, which, as opposed to the current practice of having an AC collection system combined with a DC transmission, can significantly reduce operating, maintenance, and investment costs while improving the efficiency and reliability.

The main goal of this project was to explore, investigate, model, and control a new family of DC-DC converters that will push the boundaries of efficiency, reliability, scalability, and power density. To this end, comprehensive modeling and analyses were conducted on the DC-DC Modular Multilevel Converter (MMC) topology which incorporates many key benefits for MV and HV DC-DC conversion while using the emerging SiC devices. The topology is modular, easily scalable, and can operate with soft switching, thereby maximizing the efficiency and reducing the adverse impacts of dv/dt, di/dt, and EMI. In addition, the converter feature DC short-circuit fault blocking capability, which is of utmost importance towards their exploitations in MV and HV voltage levels. 

The outcomes are the project are: (i) Detailed modeling, control and soft-switching operation of the DC-MMC over the entire range of operation, (ii) Investigation of the impact of Medium-Frequency Transformer (MFT) on the soft switching operation of the converter, and consequently, providing guidelines for the design of MFT, and (iii) Verification of the analysis, modeling, and control on a scaled-down prototype. On the educational front, the results were integrated into a few lectures of a graduate-level power electronics course.
